awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Collaborative Research: PE4GQ - Practical Encryption for Geospatial Queries on Private Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The mobile computing revolution led to the emergence of novel and exciting applications centered on geospatial data, such as location-based services, geosocial networks, and ride-sharing. These apps enable users to receive services customized to their locations and to interact with nearby peers. However, recent years also witnessed a growing number of risks associated with sharing of location data. Using location information, adversaries may stage a broad spectrum of attacks, ranging from physical surveillance and stalking, to inferring private details about an individual?s health status, political or religious affiliations, alternative lifestyles, etc. The proposed project will investigate secure and efficient techniques to protect the locations of mobile users before they are sent to online services. The focus will be on encryption, which provides a high level of protection, on the same level currently used for confidential data such as social security numbers and bank account information. Location privacy is an important component of the broader online privacy concept. Strong protection for users? whereabouts will bring significant societal benefits in the current online ecosystem, where privacy attacks occur more frequently and with far greater ramifications than before, as illustrated by recent high-profile privacy breaches that affected prominent players in the social media industry (e.g., Google, Facebook, Yahoo).

Several prior research efforts focused on protecting locations through mechanisms like location cloaking, differential privacy or geo-indistinguishability, but none of these existing approaches can properly address the challenges of online, continuous sharing of locations. The only direction that achieves a sufficient amount of protection is represented by cryptographic approaches, but despite recent breakthroughs in the area of functional encryption, processing on encrypted data is very slow and/or insufficiently expressive to support the use case scenarios required by location-centric applications. The objective of this project is to bridge the gap between geospatial applications on one side and functional encryption on the other. The proposed PE4GQ (Practical Encryption for Geospatial Queries) framework will allow researchers and practitioners to make use of encrypted search primitives on geospatial data with practical computational and communication overhead. The project will adopt existing functional encryption techniques and customize their use to the specific requirements of geospatial queries. The project will address several challenging tasks: (i) identifying a small set of representative plaintext operations that occur commonly in location-centric applications and can be used to express more complex spatial queries; (ii) identifying appropriate cryptographic building blocks that can be used to securely evaluate the operations identified in the first task; (iii) investigating data representations and query encodings that allow efficient secure evaluation by reducing the number of expensive cryptographic primitives; and (iv) investigating performance optimizations that reduce encrypted data processing overhead by taking into account information from the spatial domain (i.e., through cross-layer design).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on three objectives:

 

1. Searchable Encryption

 

Secure location-based alerts are important for healthcare (e.g., contact tracing), public safety, transportation, etc. Mobile users subscribe to secure alerts and send encrypted location updates to a service provider (SP). When an event of interest occurs, a search token is generated by a trusted authority (e.g., CDC) and the SP processes location updates directly on ciphertexts.

Encrypted search is expensive, so we devised efficient secure processing techniques. Different parts of the space have different likelihoods of becoming alert zones. We used graphs to capture the relationships between types of areas (e.g., sparse vs dense). We used graph embeddings to assigns similar codes to areas with similar likelihoods of becoming alert zones. This encoding of alert areas requires fewer cryptographic operations for matching. Results were published in DBSEC2020 and Geoinformatica2020. Next, we focused on skewed data: using public knowledge about density of the data, we derived variable-length encodings using Huffman trees, which decreased processing overhead (EDBT2021). Subsequently, we developed Markov-inspired models to characterize dynamic alert zones and facilitated encodings that allow effective processing at multiple snapshots (published in VLDBJ2023).

 

We also studied secure skyline queries, relevant to travel, healthcare, transportation, etc. We designed an approach that uses materialization and computes partitions of the space, deemed tiles, such that the result to a skyline query is the same for all possible query points in the same tile. We organized tiles into a balanced index, and ensured no leakage resulted from the structure (ICDE2021).

 

We developed optimizations that accelerate the execution of cryptographic primitives using FPGAs  (published in ACM CODASPY 2024), which benefits all of the above-mentioned techniques.

 

2. Machine Learning with Differential Privacy

 

We adapted differentially private stochastic gradient descent (DP-SGD) to the challenges of trajectory data (sparseness, skew). We designed custom neural networks based on skip grams and negative sampling while enforcing privacy. We studied mechanisms to allocate privacy budget across different stages of learning (published in EDBT2020). Although we outperformed state-of-the-art, we concluded that DP-SGD accuracy is low for geospatial data, and we shifted towards private neural databases.

 

Our neural database answers queries privately by first sanitizing data according to DP and then building an ML model on top of the private release. Doing so has two advantages: it reduces storage size, since it learns important data features, and can compress big datasets to a compact representation. Also, ML smoothens the variation in dataset characteristics. This work was published in VLDB2022 and SIGMOD2023.

 

We found that the accuracy of the model depends on the underlying sanitization techniques. We focused on the challenges of privacy-preserving multi-dimensional histograms for location data. We identified data homogeneity as an essential property that directly influences accuracy, and constructed structures that yield partitions with homogeneous data distribution. Our Homogeneous Tree Framework solution builds hierarchical data structures that preserve differential privacy and enforce density homogeneity across partitions. We outperform existing work on all datasets considered. This work and its extension to origin-destination matrices, as well as detailed cost models and strategies for spatial structure tuning, were published in SIGSPATIAL2021, EDBT2022, and TSAS 2023.

 

In addition to general techniques for spatial data, we were also able to show that the proposed techniques can be applied to related domains, such as publication of energy consumption distribution over the geospatial domain with differential privacy. This is a very important result for better understanding of consumption and planning in smart grids. The work has been accepted for publication in EDBT 2025.

 

3. Fairness

 

We obtained significant results for fairness in machine learning on spatial data, one in the context of group fairness, and the other in the context of individual fairness:

Group fairness: the fairness problem in machine learning on geospatial data can be effectively tackled if one pursues a partitioning of the input data according to criteria that control and eliminate bias. Specifically, we were able to devise a mechanism for geospatial indexing that integrates into the split decision of conventional data index structures (k-d trees) and eliminates bias. This work outperforms benchmarks adapted from the fairness literature on non-spatial data (published in EDBT2024).

Individual fairness: spatial attributes can create the possibility of discriminating, intentionally or not, against individuals based on the correlation between their sensitive attributes and their locations. For instance, individuals from underprivileged ethnic groups may congregate together in communities. In order to prevent the machine learning algorithm from exercising bias against such individuals, we devised fairness models and mechanisms for location data using our newly proposed concept of fair polynomials. This work has been published in VLDB 2023.

 

PRODUCTS

The project produced over 20 research papers, many published in top-tier venues (SIGMOD, ICDE, PVLDB, EDBT, ACM CODASPY, VLDB Journal). Software prototypes and prepared datasets were made available to the public on the project website and Github.
